html_product_description: Harness your PC's potential with the 980 SSD. Whether you need a boost for gaming or a seamless workflow for heavy graphics, the 980 is a smart choice for outstanding SSD performance — and it's all backed by an NVMe interface and PCIe 3.0 technology. Satisfy your need for speed with PCIe 3.0, using HMB technology and NVMe interface for high efficiency. The 980 delivers value, without sacrificing sequential read/write speeds up to 3,500/3,000 MB/s, over 6.2x the speed of SATA SSDs. Keep your SSD running at its peak with Full Power Mode, which drives continuous and consistent high performance. Enable through Samsung Magician software to keep your SSD in active mode with no latency, so you can instantly jump back into large intensive work files or graphics-heavy games. Unlock the full potential of 980 with Samsung Magician's advanced, yet intuitive optimization tools. Monitor drive health, optimize performance, protect valuable data, and receive important updates with Magician to ensure you're always getting the best performance out of your SSD.The NVM Express design mark is registered to NVM Express, Inc.HMB (Host Memory Buffer) technology enables the SSD to use the DRAM of the host system for read/write caching and buffering.Performance may vary depending on the SSD’s firmware version, system and hardware configuration. Performance measurements are based on IOmeter 1.1.0. The write performances were measured with Intelligent TurboWrite technology activated. The sequential write performances after Intelligent TurboWrite region are: up to 250 MB/s (250GB), 500 MB/s (500GB) and 900 MB/s (1TB). Test system configuration: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-6700K CPU @ 4.00GHz,DDR4 2133MHz 8GBx2 OS-Windows 10 Pro 64bit Asrock Z-170 Extreme7+ Results are based on a comparison with Samsung SATA SSDs.TBW : Terabytes written. For 980: 150 TBW for 250GB model, 300 TBW for 500GB model, 600 TBW for 1TB model.

reviews.title: Huge Upgrade from SATA SSD
reviews.content: I'm a video editor and recently needed to upgrade my desktop editing PC's boot drive from the original 256 GB Samsung SATA SSD (in hindsight, should have gone with more storage from the get-go, but what's done is done). I decided to go with a PCle SSD for faster speeds, and it is a night and day difference from the SATA SSD. In addition to much more space (1TB), everything is much faster. I did have a little difficulty in installation, but I think that was more of a factor of the motherboard (Asus Prime x470-Pro) and not the SSD itself. When I originally installed it in the first M2 drive, it basically disabled my wifi card. When I put it in the other M2 slot under the heatsink, that solved the problem, and everything has been running great since. I'm definitely not an expert in building computers by any means, so if I can troubleshoot it and find a fix, I'm sure anyone can.

reviews.title: Awesome!
reviews.content: Works great and I’m easy to install… BUT! It does not come with the screw required to hold it in. My 2022 Dell XPS 9520 has an additional m.2 slot but did not have a screw. Had to wait till I found a spare small eye glass screw that happen to fit in the threads to secure this. I recommends looking to see if your computer has the screw inserted before upgrading, if not be sure to order the screw!

reviews.title: 2013 Macbook Pro new life with Sintech adapter
reviews.content: Based on RSN LLC's review, I purchased this and a Sintech NGFF M.2 nVME SSD adapter for my late 2013 Macbook Pro (11,2), to replace an OWC Aura drive that was causing (well-known, it turns out) issues waking from sleep/hibernate.Like with RSN as well, I had to use a Mojave boot USB stick because my external Time Machine drive was built prior to 10.14 and so the restore tools did not recognize this new drive. Everything worked fine once I first booted from a Mojave installer, and the TIme Machine backup restored perfectly onto the new 1TB Samsung.

reviews.title: Easy to install but be aware of oriantation
reviews.content: The m.2 is an easy install but if its your first time installing make sure to double check the mothetboards m.2 slots cables/pins as to not put in upside down, my fist time doing this and luckly i didnt mess it up but it is a good note, also was a bit of a hastle to line up the in mobo heat sync but after i got it all in right it ran great with no issues

reviews.title: Good option to easily replace stock 1TB HDD in Dell XPS 8910 but order M.2 screw separately
reviews.content: After seeing how easy it was to replace the stock 1TB HDD in a Dell XPS 8930 with a slowly dying HDD by a 980 Pro using Samsung Data Migration, I decided to install another 1TB SSD in one of our older home computers, a Dell XPS 8910 that also came with a 1TB HDD.I could not, however, justify the cost of the 980 Pro on the XPS 8910, so decided to go for the 980 which is much cheaper, aware that the 980 unlike the 980 Pro does not have its own DRAM buffer and is therefore slower. The 980 offers the same 5-year warranty as the 980 Pro which was my primary requirement.I pretty much followed the same process as for the XPS 8930, but this time had a M.2 screw handy.Opened the chassis. Put the new drive in the M.2 slot. Screwed it to the standoff that was already on the motherboard using a M.2 screw ordered separately. Booted from HDD. Installed Samsung Magician and Data Migration tool using the Integrated Installer, but as on the XPS 8930, they did not see the new drive right away. Rebooted Windows once. Then somehow Samsung Magician and Data Migration tool could see the drive.Launched cloning which took just under two hours. After that the PC turned off by itself. Unplugged SATA connector from old HDD. Turned on PC which automatically booted on new drive.As on the XPS 8930, Samsung Data Migration tool did not clone my Outlook .OST file. I came to the conclusion that it relies on Windows Shadow Copy / Volume Shadow Copy Service which Microsoft has decided should not be backing up .OST file (although allegedly the registry subkey OutlookOST controls this behavior), so after I opened Outlook, my emails were not there, and it took a few hours for my mailbox to resynchronize with my ISP (we're talking multiple gigs of emails accumulated over a decade) and I lost my Outlook rules. I wish Samsung Data Migration provided some warning about this questionable behavior.Switching from HDD to SDD makes Windows and programs start much faster and I think it is worth it now that SSD prices have gone down, at least when it is so painless to do so.

reviews.title: SAMSUNG 980 SSD 1TB PCle 3.0x4, NVMe M.2 2280
reviews.content: Needed to replace a 500GB M2 2230 in a Dell laptop. Was a little wary of this being a different configuration, but it looked like it would work in the service manual. Installation was actually pretty easy. Cloning the original before installation was a bit more confusing. I had a case to use and decided to use the Samsung Magician software, but it wasn't seeing the the drive. I had read something somewhere about being sure to have the drivers, but couldn't find anything on that, and it turns out it wasn't the problem anyway. Then it occurred to me I needed to go into Disk Management and initialize (if that is the word) the drive. Once I handled that the Magician software did the job. It does warn that it clones only the OS partition, and I wish it had also copied the backup partition, but I'll find another way to get a backup. So 5 stars.
